meanings.definition: Force something unwelcome or unfamiliar to be accepted or put in place.
meanings.sent1: The teacher had to impose a new rule about no running in the hallways.
meanings.sent2: The government decided to impose a curfew to keep everyone safe.
meanings.sent3: It was quite funny to see the cat try to impose its authority on the dog.
meanings.sent4: The storm imposed its power on the small town, leaving a trail of destruction.
meanings.sent5: The strict librarian would always impose silence in the reading room.

meanings.definition: Establish or apply (a rule or law) in a forceful or unwelcome way.
meanings.sent1: The principal had to impose a ban on chewing gum in school.
meanings.sent2: The dictator would often impose harsh restrictions on the citizens.
meanings.sent3: It seemed like a joke when the robot tried to impose a bedtime on the kids.
meanings.sent4: The new manager imposed his authority on the team from day one.
meanings.sent5: The heavy rain imposed a sense of urgency on the farmers to harvest their crops.

meanings.sent1: The bully would impose his will on the smaller kids during recess.
meanings.sent2: The virus outbreak imposed a lot of stress on the healthcare system.
meanings.sent3: It was comical to watch the toddler impose his messy eating habits on the family dinner.
meanings.sent4: The haunting memories imposed a heavy burden on her heart.
meanings.sent5: The strict diet imposed by the doctor was challenging but necessary for her health.
